repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Second Addis Ababa Urban
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory, and sustainability unlikely. Political
            instability hindered implementation, conducive to
            unsatisfactory performances by both the Bank, and the
            Borrower. The key lessons convey that, both institutional
            development, and broader capacity building objectives were
            not substantially achieved, and within this context, it is
            worth mentioning that development imperatives were not fully
            incorporated into the mainstream policies, and programs of
            the Addis Ababa City Government (AACG), thus fundamental
            policy reforms, did not influence the program, nor any
            significant issues within AACG as an institution. It is
            suggested that, while the city, i.e., AACG should remain
            responsible for the provision of basic public services, it
            should not be required that all services be delivered by
            AACG, rather alternative service delivery should be
            explored. Given the high transaction costs in financing, and
            supervising individual subprojects, the Bank should provide
            "assistance" in capacity building, to further
            concentrate on the financial aspects. The Bank did however,
            address the issue of institutional strengthening, to
            articulate capacity actions, and initiate involvement with
            stakeholders, but changes in management leadership halted
            preparation efforts. It remains imperative to enable the
            city's program, and financial management capacity, to
            address poverty, and basic services delivery.

repnme.cdata!:
Ethiopia - Second Addis Ababa Urban
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is designed to provide
            continued support for the nation's capital and Akaki
            and will have the following objectives : a) improving basic
            infrastructure and environmental conditions in project
            areas; b) supporting a core housing development program
            primarily for lower-income families; c) promoting
            opportunities for poor women living in the Kebeles to
            enhance their income; d) providing assistance to urban
            service delivery agencies to carry out their activities more
            efficiently; and e) promoting the adoption of sound cost
            recovery policies and practices.  Project components include
            the following : 1) sites and services - including the
            development of 2,000 serviced plots with 1,900 core housing
            units in Addis Ababa and 350 such units in Akaki; 2) Kebele
            upgrading - including infrastructure improvements and loans
            for house improvements; 3) street maintenance; 4) solid
            waste management; 5) municipal infrastructure; 6) water
            supply improvement; and 7) institutional support program -
            including consultancy services, studies, technical
            assistance etc. to strengthen management and maintenance
            systems of project agencies.
